Niezapominckjek, Cracow 30 239 (Poland) Abstract This review points out the role of quantum chemistry in understanding the mechanism of catalytic oxidation of hydrocarbons on transition metal oxides and presents an overview of fundamental experimental information necessary to explain the elementary steps of these reactions. The problem of modelling heterogeneous catalysis is divided into three aspects: nature of the surface, interaction of atoms or molecules with the surface and the nature of the reactions occurring in the absence of catalyst. Each aspect is examined on the basis of the results obtained from quantum chemical calculations. Heterogeneous oxidation of both aliphatic (propene, butene-1) and aromatic (benzene, toluene, o-xylene) hydrocarbons is discussed as an example. Introduction Oxidation of hydrocarbons may be viewed as a reaction which consists in the abstraction of hydrogen atom(s) and addition of one or several oxygen atoms, resulting in several products which differ in the ratios C/H and C/O. Based upon various factors, oxidation reactions can be divided into different classes. One possible classification method is to separate them into selective (partial, soft) oxidation and total oxidation (combustion). Thermodynamically the most favourable are reactions of total oxidation, characterized by the largest changes in free enthalpy, AGO, and the highest O/C ratio in products. Thus, to obtain selective oxidation processes (less oxygen in products), the reaction must be kinetically controlled. This can be achieved either by modifying the reaction conditions or by the use of catalysts. Selective oxidation comprises reactions which proceed with conservation of the number of carbon atoms in the oxidized molecule and reactions which lead to partial degradation of the carbon skeleton. They can be classified into two types: those involving only the dehydrogenation process and those involving both dehydrogenation and oxygen insertion into the hydrocarbon molecule. The dehydrogenation process, which consists of cleavage of a 0304-5102/91/$3.50 0 1991- Elsevier Sequoia, Lausanne 278 C-H bond and formation of a C=C bond, converts the hydrocarbon molecule into a more unsaturated hydrocarbon. It can proceed either as a simple process without oxygen or as a process involving oxygen. In the latter case, formation of water as a byproduct provides the thermodynamic driving force for the dehydrogenation. The main features of the selective oxidation involving both dehydrogenation and oxygen insertion are cleavage of a C-H bond and formation of a C-O bond. Oxygen is required for both steps, viz. in the dehydrogenation step to form water as a byproduct and in the insertion stage to form oxygenates. From the point of view of industrial application, the most important process is selective oxidation by heterogeneous catalysis, which accounts for 21% of the total production of major organic chemicals. The main processes in this category are allylic oxidation to aldehydes, nitriles (in the presence of NH3) and acids, aromatic oxidation to acids and anhydrides, epoxidation of olefins, methanol oxidative dehydrogenation to formaldehyde and, recently of increasing importance, functionalization of paraffins. Among these processes the most significant is allylic oxidation (oxidation at the allylic position) which includes oxidation, ammoxidation, dimerization, oxydehydrogenation and acetoxylation reactions [ 1-3 ]. These processes proceed through formation of the allylic species or its homologues. Further transformations, consisting in the abstraction of the second H atom and/or addition of oxygen or an NH group, lead to formation of dienes, aldehydes, acids or nitriles, respectively. The organic molecule can react with oxygen along many possible reaction pathways, giving a number of different products. The role of the catalyst is to accelerate only one of them, very often not the thermodynamically most favourable one. This selectivity of action is the most important and characteristic feature of the catalyst and makes possible the formation of products, which in the absence of the catalyst would have never been formed because of the more rapidly proceeding competitive processes. Often a small modification of the catalyst composition or variation in the method of its preparation can modify its catalytic properties to such an extent that the direction of the reaction is changed and a new product is formed, usually with high selectivity. Catalysts used in selective oxidation processes are mixed metal oxides which are combination of transition metal oxides of Groups VA and VIA (V20o, Mo03, U03, W03) with oxides of Groups B (Bi, As, Sb, Sn, Te, P) or Group VIII (Fe, Co, Ni). The mixed oxides can form chemical compounds of the type of oxysalts (COMo04, Bi2MO06), solid solutions (Mo03 in V205) or bi-dimensional layers of one oxide deposited on another oxide as support (V205-Ti02). In the total oxidation the simple transition metal oxides (Co304, Mn02) having low valence cations are active. Catalytic properties of a given catalyst, irrespective of whether it is heterogeneous, homogeneous or enzymatic catalysis, are related to the properties of an intermediate complex composed of the reacting molecule and a group of atoms of the catalyst, constituting the active center. Un- 279 derstanding the mechanism of the catalytic process requires answering the following basic questions: - how does bonding of the molecule in the intermediate complex modify the electronic structure of this molecule, in other words what is the structure of the intermediate complex and how does it depend on the properties of the active center? - how does formation of the intermediate complex influence the reactivity of different bonds in the molecule and thus, determine the type of product formed in the course of the catalytic reaction? - where at the surface of the catalyst is the discussed intermediate complex located and to what extent do its properties relate to the localization and to the properties of the solid? - what is the role of the steric factor, i.e. how does the mutual orientation of the reacting molecules affect the type of products? - how do the electronic factors, i.e. type of frontier orbitals of the reacting molecules, determine the reaction pathway and hence the type of products formed? - do there exist any other active centers which can create other routes for parallel or consecutive transformation of the reacting molecule, leading to other unwanted products? Recent developments in modern surface techniques provide access to a wide spectrum of information on both atomic and electronic structures of a surface, its geometry and topography, as well as on the structure of adsorbed species, i.e. their chemical composition, coordination and type of bonds. However, only a limited number of isolated data about catalytic processes have been accumulated, in many cases with only slight interrelations among them. Understanding of the mechanisms of catalytic reactions is still far from satisfactory. Rapid advances in methodology and computational power allow computational chemistry to provide information which is difficult to obtain experimentally and to assist in the interpretation and understanding of experimental results. Developments in computers and their increasingly widespread availability have resulted in the emergence of quantum chemistry as a new tool in the studies of catalytic processes. Since quantum chemistry can provide fundamental insight into the elementary steps of a reaction, its methods become a strategy which is parallel and complementary to experimental techniques. The synergy between experiment and quantum chemistry may lead to better understanding of the nature of catalytic processes. The application of quantum chemistry to the problems of catalysis has been the subject of several review articles. Beran and Zahradnik [41 summarize all applications of different quantum chemical methods to catalytic problems up to 1977. Sauer [5j gives a short review of relevant approximations and techniques, as well as their use in the description of molecular and ionic crystals, semiconductors and insulators, zeolites, silica, and related materials. A general treatment of the modern theory of catalysis by solid surfaces is given in [61, whereas use of the molecular cluster approach to investigate 280 a number of solid state problems and the interaction of these surfaces with adsorbates is presented in [ 7 ]. Baetzold [ 8 ] concentrates on application of MO (Molecular Orbital) theory to the description of the properties of metal clusters and chemisorption of simple species on them. The theoretical aspects of metal clusters are discussed in detail by Koutecky and Fantucci [9], who consider alkali metal and alkaline-earth metal as well as transition metal clusters, attention being paid to the electronic structure and geometry of clusters of different sizes. Discussion of HF (Hartree Fock) and CI (Configuration Interaction) methods, density functional theories and effective potential methods is also presented. The phenomenon of chemisorption is discussed by Shustorovich [10] in terms of the PT-BOC (Perturbation Theory-Bond Order Conservation) method, which is based on analysis of some fundamental aspects of chemisorption such as periodic trends in heat of chemisorption and acceptor behavior of adsorbates. Quantum chemical aspects of chemical bonding to metal surfaces by means of Frontier Orbital Theory are investigated by van Santen in [ 111. More general in the sense of dealing not only with the metal catalysts are the papers of Colbourn [ 12 ] and van Hove et al. [131. The former concentrates on adsorption and reaction on clusters of metals, ionic and covalent materials as well as on their surface structure and stability. Problems of poisoning and promotion are also discussed and a review of theoretical studies on zeolites is given. Van Hove et al. [ 13 ] describe several methods of theoretical surface chemistry, stressing their significant contribution to the understanding of surface structural chemistry. Additionally they provide information on the various experimental techniques that are used and the types of structural information obtained. Hoffmann [ 14 ], in an excellent and very illustrative manner demonstrates how to link chemistry and physics by giving an interpretation of delocalized band structure from a chemical point of view. This paper can serve as one of the few common bases between chemists and physicists and between their specific languages. Theoretical studies on zeolites, including structural simulation, cation localization, zeolite acidity, the influence of electrostatic effect upon the structure and properties as well as on adsorption on zeolites, are presented in [ 15 ]. The impact of quantum chemistry on studies of the mechanism of chemical reactions is summarized by Jug [ 16 ] and by Friedrich et al. [ 17 ], who give a brief survey of existing MO theories applied to the question of chemical reaction [ 16 ] and the outline of dynamic and static approaches to the theoretical studies of reaction mechanisms. The aim of the article, addressed to both theoreticians and experimentalists, is to give an overview of fundamental experimental information required to understand the mechanism of catalytic heterogeneous oxidation of hydrocarbons on transition metal oxide catalysts and to present the role of quantum chemical methods in the explanation of elementary steps of these reactions. Since in modelling heterogeneous catalysis it is convenient to subdivide the problem into three aspects, viz. the nature of the surface, interaction of atoms or molecules with the surface and nature of the reactions 281 occurring in the absence of catalyst, this paper includes discussion of the activation step of both reacting molecules, a description of the catalysts and studies of the direct reaction between different oxygen species and various forms of the molecule to be oxidized. The paper is based upon studies carried out by the author using quantum chemistry methods and upon selected information from the literature. Interaction of reactants with the surface of the catalyst Chemisorption, the chemical binding of an atom or molecule (adsorbate) to a solid surface (adsorbent or substrate), is one of the steps in the process of heterogeneous catalysis. Theory of chemisorption can provide energy hypersurfaces E(R) as well as a description of the electronic structure of the bond between the adsorbate and adsorption site on the surface, and therefore stands between solid state theory and the theory of molecules. The solid provides a surface with many adsorption sites, an infinite reservoir of electrons with constant chemical potential, and continuum of excited states. Chemisorption of molecules leads to the appearance of a discrete resonance structure of the excitation spectrum. During chemisorption the discrete states of the isolated molecule are coupled to the continuum of the solid leading usually to a shift and broadening of the molecular states. Theoretical approaches to the description of chemisorption are reviewed in the monograph [ 18 ], in which chemisorption on oxides, semiconductors and both simple and transition metals is discussed and solid surfaces as well as clusters are considered. The existing theoretical approaches are briefly reviewed also by Muscat and Newns [19] (examples of chemisorption of hydrogen, oxygen, alkalies on transition metals) and by Schonhammer [20] (chemisorption of hydrogen on metals). The general features of the LCAO MO, Green's function formalism, multiple-scattering Xa methods, their applications to chemisorption with emphasis on the localization of bonding in surface complexes are given by Danese and Schrieffer [21 ]. Activation of oxygen In oxidation reactions two reactants take part: oxygen species and the molecule to be oxidized. FYom the point of view of thermodynamics practically all organic compounds are not stable with respect to oxygen. The fact that at normal temperature only few chemical . compounds react spontaneously with oxygen is due to the high bond energy in the oxygen molecule, which is responsible for the significant activation energy of uncatalyzed oxidation reaction. One of the most important functions of a catalyst in the oxidation process is the activation of oxygen by its adsorption and/or incorporation into the 282 oxide crystal lattice. One should not forget that the surface oxygen atoms of the oxide may also participate in the catalytic reaction. In order to understand catalytic oxidation it is essential to study the behaviour and properties of oxygen adsorbed on the catalyst as well as the nature of the surface oxygen atoms. The nature and properties of adsorbed and surface oxygen atoms are usually characterized by one of the following features: - bond energy M-O or related parameters (heat of adsorption or desorption, heat of decomposition of oxide) as well as kinetic properties (for example isotope exchange energy); - charge of oxygen species; - structure of M-O complexes (both those forming on the surface and those constituting the structure of oxide). Results of the experimental studies indicate that catalysts for selective and total oxidation processes differ in the bond energy of the oxygen. Catalysts active in total oxidation are characterized by weakly bonded oxygen on the surface or in the bulk, whereas in the case of catalysts for selective oxidation the bond energy of oxygen is much higher. At the catalyst surface oxygen can be present in a continuous range of species, from electron-deficient to electron-rich, from mono- to poly-oxygen species depending on the sample history. These oxygen atoms and ions may have charges and binding energies different from those of the lattice oxygen and may be desorbed at different temperatures. Adsorbed oxygen is identifiable only on the stoichiometric surface of a fully oxidized oxide. On the partially reduced surface reoxidation of the surface cations proceeds, the degree of reoxidation depending on the extent of charge transfer between the reduced center and the adsorbed oxygen. If an adsorbed oxygen species acquires, due to charge transfer, the same electron density as the surface lattice oxygen ion and if it occupies a lattice site - the adsorbed oxygen becomes a lattice oxygen and the surface is reoxidized. Thus, one can consider oxygen as adsorbed only if the charge transfer is less extensive and/or the oxygen species does not occupy the site of lattice oxygen. The occurrence and identification of oxygen species adsorbed at oxide surfaces is reviewed in two papers by Che and Tench [22, 23] and also in the book by Bielanski and Haber [24]. Here, only the main features of the surface oxygen species will be summarized. Two types of monooxygen species may be distinguished: O- ions formed either by adsorption or from surface oxide ions of the lattice and OZ- ions of the lattice in low coordination (LC) and/or double bonded to transition metal ions, M=O. Occurrence of very reactive O- ion even at low temperatures is well established. The formation of its aggregates, such as dimers or trimers, is also suggested. The OZ- ion which in the gas phase is not stable (positive enthalpy of formation), can be stabilized at the surface by interaction with neighbouring ions. The stabilizing Madelung potential depends on the coordination number of the discussed ion, and at surfaces, edges, corners or any defects, is weaker than in the bulk. The consequences are manifested by lowering the energy of such ions and their tendency either to undergo 283 transformation into an O- ion by release of an electron or to become the donor of the electron pair in the presence of an electrophilic moiety. The existence of these low coordination ions at the surface is postulated but not yet proven. Another type of 02- ion exists, where ions are double bonded to metal centers, M=O. In contrast to oxygen ions common to at least two M-O polyhedra, i.e. to oxygen bonded to metal atoms in a chain, M-O-M, double bonded oxygens occupy terminal positions in polyhedra, being bonded exclusively to one metal ion. The difference with previously discussed oxygen ions follows from the weakly polarized M=O bond. Evidence for the existence of M=O species on the surface is very strong. The 02- ions, although having no oxidizing properties, play a crucial role in the oxidation reaction. They can act either as nucleophilic ligands entering into the reagent molecule or can accept protons abstracted during the adsorption of hydrocarbons. When discussing dioxygen species on the surface, superoxide 02- and peroxide 022- ions as well as reversibly bonded oxygen molecules [25] are to be taken into consideration. So far there is no evidence for the presence of the 023- and 02+ species on the surface; however these ions are postulated in the literature. For example compounds containing 02+ ions are known but the formation of such adsorbed species is very unlikely because the oxidation of neutral dioxygen proceeds only in presence of the strongest oxidation reactants. The presence of triplet molecular oxygen adsorbed reversibly is generally accepted. The formation of more reactive, activated singlet molecular oxygen is suggested but the evidence for its existence is indirect. The superoxide ion 02- is the most stable oxygen moiety in the gas phase and it is also present in superoxides of alkali metals. Its occurrence at the surface is well established. Unstable in the gas phase, 022- ion can exist in the solid due to the crystal field stabilizing effect. The 02- and 022ions are unstable at higher temperature and decompose, most probably forming O-. One can also discuss polyoxygen species like 03- and 04- ions. The existence of ozonide ion 03-, containing three equivalent oxygens, which decomposes at room temperature to form 02- ion is documented. There is also supposition about another 03- species with different characteristics (two equivalent nuclei). The data for 04- ion indicate that it is likely to exist on surfaces under special conditions. In summary, oxygen is always chemisorbed in the form of negatively charged species linked to a surface by a bond of a high degree of ionicity. There are no available thermodynamic data concerning the energy of formation of surface oxygen species. With the exception of 022- and 02-, all other negative mono- and poly-nuclear oxygen species are paramagnetic and may be investigated by the EPR method, which in fact is the most important tool for studying the properties of oxygen species. The properties of surface oxygen species depend strongly on the nature of the oxide and on the reaction conditions; they cannot therefore be discussed as entities separate 284 from the environment. Many oxides generate at their surfaces a wide spectrum of various oxygen moieties depending on the reaction conditions. In the oxidation reaction, oxygen can be involved in the following elementary processes: abstraction of hydrogen or proton from an adsorbed organic molecule to give a radical or carboanion; attack on an organic molecule; and the reoxidation process, i.e. replenishment of a lattice oxygen ion. For example, in the case of oxide catalysts hydrogen abstraction, particularly fast with O- ion, takes place also with OLc2-, 02- and 03ions. The O- ion may appear as an intermediate in the reduction as well as in the reoxidation of the surface of the oxide catalyst and may also take part in a direct reaction with other reagents [26]. The essential role of the double-bonded M=O ions in the selective oxidation of hydrocarbons was postulated by Trifiro et al. [27, 28] for the oxidation of propylene and by Akimoto et al. [29-31 ] in the case of butadiene oxidation. The form of the particular oxygen species taking part in a specific oxidation reaction is still far from being established. In various oxidation processes, different oxygen species can participate depending on the type of process (i.e. type of organic molecule and type of catalyst). The various types of oxygen species can be also classified into electrophilic (neutral singlet 02, 02-, O-) and nucleophilic (02-, 022-) agents [32]. Consequently, the oxidation processes may be divided into electrophilic oxidation starting with preliminary activation of the oxygen species, and nucleophilic oxidation beginning with preliminary activation of the hydrocarbon molecule. - Electrophilic oxygen species attack organic molecules in the region of highest electron density, the ar bonds. The reaction results either in the formation of peroxy- and epoxy-complexes which can play the role of precursors of organic oxides (the case of reaction in liquid phase) or in the formation of an intermediate which, under conditions of heterogeneous catalytic reaction, undergoes degradation of the carbon skeleton. Results of experiments [33] indicate that whenever electrophilic species exist at the surface of the catalyst, hydrocarbons undergo total oxidation. This is due to the fact that the attack of electrophilic oxygen is much faster than the insertion of nucleophilic oxygen. - The nucleophilic oxygen species, 02- or 022-, have no oxidizing properties but can be inserted into activated hydrocarbon molecules in the course of nucleophilic addition. Such reactions lead to the formation of oxygenated products which desorb leaving oxygen vacancies at the surface of the catalyst. In the case of nucleophilic oxidation it is the cation of the catalyst which acts as oxidizing agent and forms the activated hydrocarbon species (via abstraction of hydrogen), which undergoes nucleophilic attack by oxygen ions. Hydrogen abstraction and nucleophilic addition of oxygen require different active centers. Incorporation of oxygen from the gas phase to fill oxygen vacancies and to reoxidize the reduced cations may not take place at the same site from which surface oxygen is inserted into the hydrocarbon, oxygen then being transported through the lattice. 285 Both types of oxidation reactions may be further systematized according to the number of elementary structural transformations introduced into the reacting molecule [34]. Along the electrophilic route the smallest structural changes consist in the destruction of double bonds via addition of oxygen (oxidation of olefins into oxides, oxyhydration of olefins to saturated ketones). More significant structural change is the fission of the double bond resulting in formation of saturated aldehydes (in the case of olefin oxidation) or anhydrides (in the case of aromatics where the ring structure undergoes fission). The most severe structural transformation introduced into the reacting molecule by electrophilic oxygen is complete destruction of the carbon skeleton, i.e. combustion into COZ and H20. Along the nucleophilic route the mildest structural change consists in the abstraction of hydrogen atoms (oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes and alkenes into dienes, oxidative dehydrodimerization or dehydrocyclization). More pronounced structural changes are involved when oxygen is incorporated via nucleophilic addition into the organic molecule, either into the hydrocarbon chain (oxidation of alkenes into unsaturated aldehydes or ketones) or into the acyl group (oxidation of aldehydes or ketones). The addition of an oxygen atom into the acyl group is equivalent to the incorporation of the second oxygen into the organic molecule and results in the formation of acids (oxidation of aldehydes) or anhydrides (oxidation of alkyl aromatics). It should be remembered that nitrogen can also play a role of heteroatom and can be introduced into organic molecule in the ammoxidation reaction. In the literature there is no theoretical study devoted explicitly to the problem of chemisorption of dioxygen or oxygen species on the surface of transition metal oxides, although a few papers deal indirectly with this subject. All available data (both experimental and theoretical) allow classification of the interaction between molecule and oxide surface into one of the following types: - nondissociative adsorption (molecular adsorption), which can take place on a single coordinatively unsaturated surface ion; the interaction follows here from o donation and/or 7r back-donation, - dissociative adsorption, in which a molecule dissociates upon adsorption; the dissociation can proceed as either heterolytic breaking of a bond (the molecule is then dissociated into charged species) which usually requires a pair of coordinatively unsaturated anion-cation sites, or homolytic bond cleavage in which neutral species are formed, - abstractive adsorption, when the adsorbate abstracts from the surface a species (usually a proton); the resulting adsorbed cationic species interact with the surface by electrostatic force; the coordinatively unsaturated surface ions are not involved in this type of adsorption, - reductive adsorption, whereby two simultaneous processes occur: the oxidation of an adsorbed molecule and the reduction of the surface; reductive adsorption may also be abstractive (e.g. oxidation of hydrocarbon to carboxylate utilizing the lattice oxygen while reducing the cation). Reductive adsorption is typical for transition metal oxides which have cations characterized by multiple oxidation states. When a reagent molecule contacts the surface of an oxide catalyst, it may become adsorbed in different forms depending on its structure and on the properties of active centers present at the surface. Different intermediate surface complexes resulting from various forms of adsorption and corresponding to different types of activation of adsorbed species may transform into different products. This chemical approach to the problem of studying the interaction of adsorbates with surfaces focuses on the local aspects of the problem. One should however keep in mind other, dynamic aspects of catalytic phenomena. The reactants of a catalytic reaction are in dynamic interaction with the solid catalyst. Continuous exchange of matter and energy between the catalyst and the reactants leads to many phenomena, such as the change of composition of the gas phase (reacting catalytic mixture) or the change of surface composition (structure and properties) which modify the catalyst activity and selectivity. Selected properties of transition metal oOdes Understanding the mechanism of a catalytic reaction proceeding at the surface of metal oxides requires a detailed knowledge of the electronic 300 properties of the surface which are responsible for the interaction and bonding with an adsorbate, for the resulting bond changes and what follows, the reaction between adsorbed reactants and the desorption process. Metal oxides are capable of participation in the exchange of electrons, protons or oxide ions. The use of oxides in catalysis is discussed in [ 121 ]. Among oxides, by far the most important are transition metal oxides as being basic materials for the chemical, electronics and electrochemical industries. These compounds have partially filled d orbitals which are responsible for a wide variety of electronic, magnetic and catalytic properties. One of the vast field of applications of transition metal oxides is catalysis and in particular, processes of selective oxidation of hydrocarbons [ 122 ]. The surface of the catalyst for selective oxidation has to perform a complex multistep operation on the reacting molecules, hindering simultaneously such interactions which could result in unwanted by-products. Experimental evidence collected in recent years indicates that the most efficient catalysts for selective oxidation of hydrocarbons are based on Group V, VI and VII transition metal oxides. The `special' chemistry of these oxides (especially of V and Mo) results from a number of interrelated factors. The considerable extension of their d wavefunctions (which are not involved in the Me-O o- bond) with respect to the equilibrium distance between neighbouring atoms allows overlap with oxygen p orbitals of -rr symmetry. Additionally, their redox potentials relative to the anion valence band edge are favorable for bond formation [ 1231. As a result 7r bonds with oxygen are formed, the cations being shifted from the centers of octahedra towards terminal oxygen atoms. Large displacement polarizabilities give rise to high relaxation energies which decrease the cation-cation repulsions opposing formation of a structure with shorter metal-metal distances. Removal of oxygen ions from the lattice of these oxides generates ordered arrays of vacancies and is followed by facile rearrangement of coordination polyhedra resulting in the formation of shear planes. Such easy passage of one oxygen ion in the transformation from a corner-linked into an edge-linked arrangement of metal-oxygen octahedra is believed to be a factor allowing these structures to insert oxygen into organic species during the process of selective oxidation of hydrocarbons [ 76 ]. Many transition metal ions (in particular Ti, V, Mo, W) possess multiple stable oxidation states, which results in the easy conversion between oxides of different stoichiometry by oxidation or reduction. This is believed to be another important factor for these oxides to function as catalysts in selective oxidation. The formal oxidation states of transition metals in oxides vary in a wide range from one (Cu20) to eight (Os04). The true ionic charge is less than predicted from the formal oxidation number and is determined by experiment or may be estimated theoretically. Crystallites of transition metal oxides may exhibit two types of crystal faces [ 1241: - the face of chemically saturated atoms exposing either metal cations with empty d orbitals which may function as LUMOs of the oxide and behave 301 like electron acceptor sites, or oxygen ions bridging the Me-Ox polyhedra, with free electron pairs, which may act as HOMOs and play a role of electrondonor sites. Such a hydrophobic face may be responsible for activation of the hydrocarbon and preparation of a nucleophilic addition of oxygen into the organic species. When a hydrocarbon approaches such a face, the C-H bond reacts with empty d orbitals, the proton being shifted to bridging oxygen and the allyl species attaches to the cation. The empty antibonding (LUMO) C-H orbital of a methylene group of such a surface species may now interact with the lone electron pair of the surface bridging oxygen (oxide HOMO), leading to the nucleophilic addition and formation of the precursor of aldehyde; - the face built of coordinatively unsaturated cations and anions, where excess charges accumulate, generating significant variations of the potential along the surface. Such hydrophilic faces show a tendency to adsorb water molecules in a dissociative manner. The interaction of an acidic OH group with hydrocarbon results in the formation of a carbonium ion. Dehydration of the surface (on heating at higher temperature) results in the generation of coordinatively unsaturated cations (Lewis acids) and 02- ions (Lewis bases). Such pairs of sites may induce heterolytic bond scission in the adsorbed reactant. The reducing atmosphere of the reaction leads to the generation of lower valent metal cations which may activate an oxygen molecule to its electrophilically active forms. The different behaviors of various crystal faces indicates that the preparation of an active and selective catalyst requires a compromise among several opposing tendencies. Additional difficulties follow from the fact that the surfaces of crystallites are never perfect and contain steps, kinks, etc. which may act as active sites. The electronic structure of the surface of transition metal oxides is determined by its atomic structure but also reflects the bulk properties. The electronic states characteristic for the surface and interesting from the catalytic point of view lie near the Fermi energy (or valence state). Such states are either partially occupied by electrons (where they can donate and accept electrons from the molecule interacting with the surface) or close enough to the filled valence band (or empty conduction band) providing a pair of states to simultaneously accept or donate electrons to the interacting molecules. The nature of surface state depends on the type and position of the ions. This is due to the fact that the results of many studies done by various physicochemical methods show the dominant role of local factors and reveal the nature of active sites in heterogeneous catalysis. The acidbase properties of the surface may be discussed in terms of Lewis (transfer of electrons pair) or Bronsted (transfer of proton) definitions (see for example [125, 144] and references therein). The Lewis definition is more general than the Bronsted definition. The Lewis acidic centers are acceptors of electron pairs; Lewis basic centers donate electron pairs. Acceptance or donation of electrons pairs by Lewis-type sites on the surface occur in order to form coordination bonds with the molecules of donor or acceptor properties, 305 respectively. All cations are acidic centers whereas all anions form basic sites. Bronsted centers may dissociate with liberation of protons; basic Br6nsted sites can accept protons. According to such a definition neutral as well as positive or negative ions may act as acidic and basic Bronsted sites. The terms `acidity' or 'basicity' is ambiguous. To describe acido-basic properties of a solid one should determine the nature of centers, their number per unit surface area and their strength [ 1281. The acido-basic features of solids substantially overlap with the acceptor and donor surface states [145]; both approaches are parallel and complementary. Lewis acidic sites as well as acceptor surface states are associated with a strong affinity towards electrons whereas the opposite is true for basic sites or donor surface states. Although transition metal oxides are used in a great number of heterogeneously catalysed processes, the properties of their surface (the nature of the active site) and of their bulk (electronic band structure) are features which are still not fully understood. In order to derive a comprehensive and complete picture of the oxide (bulk and surface) a wide range of topics have to be studied by the common use of different experimental techniques and theoretical approaches. Solid oxide catalysts expose a large variety of 310 active centers. The type and density of these centers are determined by the reaction conditions (state of oxidation-reduction, hydration, temperature etc.) At the surface of metal oxides with only one stable oxidation state the role of active centers is performed by coordinatively unsaturated surface cations or anions which act as acidic or basic sites. In the case of oxides of multivalent metals which form a series of oxides corresponding to different oxidation states, active sites include surface cations in different oxidation states. The nature of the active sites present at the surface and the ability of transition metal oxides to form different types of bonding between coordination polyhedra are the most important factors in determining their catalytic properties. Direct reaction between hydrocarbon and oxygen molecules The reaction between hydrocarbon and oxygen molecules which starts either by an activation of oxygen or by an activation of hydrocarbon, may follow various reaction pathways giving a number of different products. A catalyst, by interacting with the reacting molecule, modifies some selected bonds within the molecule (without activating all others), facilitates the rearrangement of bonds and, directs the reaction along a certain selected pathway which permits formation of one chosen product with very high selectivity. A fundamental question may be raised: which parameters determine that the reacting system selects a given reaction pathway out of many possible alternatives? This subject has a direct bearing upon the fundamental problem of catalysis and involves the role of steric and electronic factors imposed upon the reacting molecules by their interactions with the surface of the catalyst, in determining the selectivity of the catalytic reaction. It seemed therefore of interest to study a model system composed of various oxygen species approaching the organic molecules from different directions. Such investigations of the direct reactions between the reactants performed parallel to the studies concerned with adsorption may provide complementary information and play a fundamental role in understanding the mechanism of oxidation reactions. One of the theoretical descriptions which may be used to discuss the problem of selection of the reaction pathways which lead to the desired products is based upon the concept of the potential energy surface (PES) [ 180-188 ]. A detailed knowledge of PES, permits description of a process of converting reactants into products involving one or more elementary reactions (i.e. concerted processes in which one or more bonds disappear and/or are formed or are regrouped [ 189 ]). Chemical reactions and conformational changes correspond to paths of minimal energy of PESs. The pathway for reactions with a barrier is a curve on a multidimensional potential energy surface which connects minima and passes through saddle points. In any point the reaction pathway is perpendicular to the isoenergetic curves i.e. the reaction pathway is the steepest descent path when going from the saddle point to the minima. The minima on the PES (characterized 311 by all positive eigenvalues of the corresponding second derivatives matrix called the force constant matrix, or Hessian) represent reactants, products and intermediates, whereas first order saddle points (points with one negative eigenvalue of the respective Hessian matrix) are associated with active complexes (transition states). The reaction coordinate, which is usually considered as a synonym of the reaction path, is a one-dimensional representation, i.e. a measurable curve along the reaction pathway. An advantage of the quantum chemical approach over experimental methods is that it is possible to study all parts of the PES, whereas with experimental techniques only those parts of the PES are accessible which are close to stable structures. Detailed understanding of the mechanism of a chemical reaction requires a knowledge of PES, which must be determined point by point by quantum chemical methods because in general it is not available analytically. The construction of PES is a difficult and time-consuming procedure, especially when a system of large size is under consideration (as is usually the case with catalysis). This is due to the need to determine an energy grid containing n" points, where v is the number of variables on which the energy depends and n is the number of values of each variable required to characterize the PES [ 190, 1911. There are several methods to reduce the dimensionality of the problem. One consists in the selection of one or two degrees of freedom as independent variables keeping the remaining ones constant, or better, optimizing them for each value of the independent variables [ 192 ]. One can also apply functionfitting techniques to generate an analytic function representing the reduced PES [ 193 ], or to locate only certain, chemically interesting, points on PES (minima, saddle points) by considering all degrees of freedom [194]. There are also approaches which follow curved reaction paths with comparatively large step sizes and which do not require the calculation of the Hessian at all points along the path [183]. Another possibility is to limit the discussion to `intuitive reaction paths'. This class of reaction pathways has one common feature: a geometric parameter such as bond distance (which is to be broken) or bond angle is intuitively chosen as a reaction coordinate. The energy is calculated in each step along this coordinate by minimalization with respect to all or several other internal coordinates. An alternative and very promising method is to limit the calculations to only those reaction pathways characterized by the lowest energy barriers and what follows, which are assumed to be the most probable pathways [195]. The choice of such a reaction pathway may rely upon the form of the potential energy surface at large distances between the reactants. This assumption is based on experimental data which suggest that the form of the transition state is determined already in the preliminary stage of the reaction. The energy gradient evaluated from the difference of the total energies at two arbitrarily chosen points on the reaction coordinate at relatively long distances between the reacting molecules may serve as the indication of the potential energy barrier encountered on approach from the given 312 direction. The attack from above the plane, parallel to the diagonal is associated with a relatively high energy barrier corresponding to the stretching of the O-O bond and evolves further towards the transition state with bridging oxygen, which may undergo rearrangement to maleic anhydride. The attack of dioxygen onto the methylene group (activated toluene) is equivalent to the oxidation of activated o-xylene molecule. For example the attack of perpendicularly oriented OZ molecule onto the -CH2 group which in the case of o-xylene leads to o-xylene peroxide proceeds even easier in the case of toluene. When atomic oxygen approaches the non-activated toluene molecule the most probable direction of an attack is that perpendicular to the ring and pointing towards the ring C-H bond. The minima on the potential energy 326 maps, corresponding to the in-plane attack on the C=C bond of the ring as well as on the methyl group, are less pronounced. In the case where the reaction between activated toluene and atomic oxygen is studied, the most susceptible point of attack is the carbon atom of the -CHZ group. The results of the calculations obtained when discussing the oxidation of toluene confirm the conclusions drawn from the analysis of the oxidation of benzene and o-xylene molecules. The oxidation of both the aromatic ring and of the methyl group proceeds along similar pathways for benzene and for its alkyl substituted derivatives. Shaik [220] discusses the problem of barrier height for nucleophilic attack on cation radicals and cations. Reaction path calculations for the interaction of ethylene radical cation with triplet molecular oxygen are reported in [221] (MNDO). Reaction between singlet molecular oxygen and propylene is one of the subjects investigated by Yamaguchi et al. [222, 2231 and reviewed by Frimer [224]. The goal of the present calculations concerning the direct reaction between reactants was to answer the following fundamental questions: - what is the reactivity of the given molecule towards other molecules of the system, and which products may be formed as the result of such an interaction - how does the reactivity of the reactants towards each other vary by altering their electronic state (for example by activating one of the reactants) - what is the relation between the spatial arrangement of the reactants and the type of products formed in the course of the reaction - what is the molecular description of the reaction in terms of breaking and/or forming chemical bonds and in terms of the transfer of electrons among reactants and catalyst. Quantum chemical analysis of the reaction between different hydrocarbons and oxygen species leads to following general conclusions concerning the oxidation reactions: - the course of the oxidation process depends on the preliminary activation of reactants (hydrocarbon and/or oxygen) and on the mutual orientation of the reacting molecules; the systems react along different pathways depending on these factors, which are imposed by the properties of the active centers at the surface of the catalyst; - the type of product is determined by the site of oxygen attack; the attack onto the C=C double bond results in the splitting of the carbon skeleton 327 and leads to products of selective oxidation which have a smaller number of carbon atoms in comparison to reagents; attack on the carbon atom results in addition of oxygen and gives the products of allylic oxidation, i.e. the oxygenated species with the same number of carbons as the oxidized molecule; the degree of oxygenation (alcohol, aldehyde or ketone, acid) depends on the direction of the attack of oxygen species, in particular on the mutual arrangement of hydrogen atoms and attacking oxygen - in the presence of an electrophilic oxygen species the oxidation reaction always proceeds according to the electrophilic mechanism independent of the preliminary activation of the hydrocarbon molecule; the attack of electrophilic oxygen is faster than the activation of hydrocarbon; the abstraction of H atom from hydrocarbon molecule (activation of the molecule) opens new sites (atoms) for the electrophilic addition reactions; - oxidation reaction proceeds along the nucleophilic mechanism only under condition that no electrophilic oxygen species are available; - the role of the catalyst is to facilitate the transfer of electrons between reactants, which is a prerequisite for the reaction which cannot be effected directly. An adequate theoretical description of the catalytic reaction requires reasonable models for the bulk, the surface, the adsorbate-surface bond, chemical reaction and an appropriate theoretical treatments. One of the examples of the unifield approach to chemisorption and heterogeneous catalysis is the method proposed by Shustorovich and Baetzold [225]. The current theory is reliable and efficient enough to explain many experimental results, and provide data which are difficult to obtain experimentally. It can also suggest new ideas but only under the condition that it is used in a `smart' way. It is obvious that quantum chemical calculations cannot replace experiment and that in order to understand the mechanism of a catalytic reaction it is necessary to combine experience gained in experiments and theoretical treatments. The full solution of the problem concerning the mechanism of chemical reactions on the basis of first principles of quantum mechanics is still a distant objective because it requires a dynamic description. Such dynamic studies although quite extensive in the area of chemical reactions are still limited to simple reactions. Complete analysis of chemically important reactions, even by means of static approaches, usually demands sophisticated quantum chemical techniques like ab initio followed by CI calculations which are difficult to apply to catalytic processes because of the size of the systems discussed. Another problem is connected with the models used to mimic the surface of catalyst and the chemisorption process. It should be remembered that by definition the model is incomplete with respect to the real object. The goal of the model is the interpretation of the chemical reaction and the prediction of the behavior of the chemical system under conditions imposed by the surrounding environment. Different models referring to the same system usually select different features of the object and this is a reason why it is 328 valuable to compare various models. The criteria which the model should fulfill, as well as aspects of model design and of utilization of the model, are discussed in [226]. In order to understand the mechanism of catalytic reactions it is very convenient to look separately at different aspects of the problem, but finally it is necessary to combine the information obtained. A good example of such an approach is provided in the paper by Blyholder and Lawles [227], which analyses the similarities and differences among homogeneous catalysis, heterogeneous catalysis and uncatalyzed reaction. The aim of the present studies was to show that simple, semi-empirical quantum chemical methods are sometimes sufficient for this purpose and can offer a great deal of information regarding the mechanism of chemical reactions.
